qas.question: What major event preceded the growth of the divide in education between White and Black Americans?
What was considered to be a major cause of the increase in educational gap?
What did returning black veterans not receive?

answers.text: loans at the same rate as whites

qas.question: How many servicemen and women were educated as a result of the GI Bill?
What opportunities were few for black veterans?
What major event preceded the growth of the divide in education between White and Asian Americans?
What was not considered to be a major cause of the increase in educational gap?

plausible_answers.text: loans at the same rate as whites

qas.question: What did returning white veterans not receive?
How many servicemen and women weren't educated as a result of the GI Bill?
What opportunities were few for hispanic veterans?

context: Following the <a0_0>end of <b5_0>World War II<b5_0/><a0_0/> the educational gap between White and Black Americans was widened by <a1_0><b6_0>Dwight D. Eisenhower's GI Bill<b6_0/><a1_0/>. This piece of legislation paved the way for white GIs to attend college. Despite their veteran status returning black servicemen were not afforded <a2_0><b7_0>loans at the same rate as whites<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Furthermore, at the time of its introduction, segregation was still the law of the land barring blacks from the best institutions. Overall, "<a3_0>Nearly <b8_0>8 million<b8_0/><a3_0/> servicemen and servicewomen were educated under the provisions of the GI Bill after World War II. But for blacks, <a4_0><b9_0>higher educational<a4_0/> opportunities<b9_0/> were so few that the promise of the GI Bill went largely unfulfilled."
